Defence - policy, planning and administration
1. All infrastructure and physical security improvements at 13 military bases are completed

comment.narrative: 5 military units
-As part of phase II, support improvements at 2 SALW storages (Homiel and Kolasava). - Conduct official opening of the completed Homiel SALW storage.

- Infrastructure of 1 SALW storage was fully improved within 2015, partial improvements were made at 1 more SALW storage. - Official opening of the completed Homiel SALW storages took place on 17 March 2015 with participation of UNDP, OSCE, EC, Ministry of Defense, Homiel local authorities and mass media representatives. The event was widely covered by mass media.

• Installation of fire alarm and security systems at the SALW storage located in the Marjina Horka military unit, thus making the site fully upgraded • Installation of perimeter fencing at the SALW storage located in the Hrodna military unit • Capital repair of the SALW storage located in the Hrodna military unit

• Installation of fire alarm and security systems at the SALW storage located in the Marjina Horka military unit, thus making the site fully upgraded • Installation of perimeter fencing at the SALW storage located in the Hrodna military unit • Capital repair of the SALW storage located in the Hrodna military unit • Installation of lightning protection and electrical cable (first two stages of installation of electrical lighting at the SALW storage located in the Hrodna military unit).

title.narrative: Maria Sharapova Foundation Scolarship for Youth

description.narrative: Maria Sharapova Foundation Scholarship for Youth from the Chernobyl-affected Areas of Belarus
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for women 15+ years old
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for men 15+ years old
total number of new full-time equivalent jobs created

number of additional males benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions

The main goal is to provide gifted and talented but economically disadvantaged youth from Chernobyl-affected regions of Belarus with the financial means necessary to pursue studies in two educational establishments approved by the Foundation.
independent political entity
policy, planning and administration

- Number of Selection Committees established. - Number of students from the Chernobyl-affected areas receiving Maria Sharapova Scholarships. - Number of visibility events with participation of UNDP, Ministry of Emergency Situations, Belarusian State University, Belarusian Academy of Arts.

comment.narrative: - No Maria Sharapova Scholarship mechanism established and functioning in the selected universities in Belarus. - No Maria Sharapova Scholarships awarded to outstanding students of fine arts and other fields in Belarus, covering the full cycle of studying leading to the award of a degree.
- The Selection Committee at the Academy of Arts is operational. - Number of students from the Chernobyl-affected areas receiving Maria Sharapova Scholarships. - At least two visibility events.

- The Selection Committee at the Academy of Arts was operational. - Seven students from the Chernobyl-affected areas, pursuing studies at the Academy of Arts, received Maria Sharapova Scholarships. - Two visibilty events condcuted. The was a presentation of the project at the exhibition of the UN projects on 29 January 2015, which was a side event to the unprecedental international conference “Strengthening Belarus – UN Development Cooperation: Results, Perspective and Emerging Opportunities”. The second venue was provided during the UN70Express for Sustainable development goals.

description.narrative: PIMS:4290 CC FSP "Belarus: LGGE Improving Energy Efficiency in Residential Buildings"

title.narrative: Report on the Results of the Inception Stage
UNDP/GEF project: "Improving Energy Efficiency in Residential Buildings in the Republic of Belarus"
Improving Energy Efficiency in Residential Buildings in the Republic of Belarus
Improving Energy Efficiency in Residential Buildings in the Republic of Belarus

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women
total number of people with improved access to energy as a result of UNDP-supported intervention
The objective of the project is to reduce the energy consumption and related GHG emissions with the focus on new residential buildings.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Construction of the pilot energy efficient residential building in Minsk

description.narrative: seat of a first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Construction of the pilot energy efficient building in Mahilyow

description.narrative: seat of a first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Construction of the pilot energy efficient residential building in Hrodna

description.narrative: Energy - power generation
To reduce the energy consumption and related GHG emissions with the focus on new residential buildings
Amount of reduced CO2 emissions compared to the projected baseline

comment.narrative: Lifetime reduction of 220000 tons of CO2eq resulting from the energy saving in buildings for which the construction has started or which have adopted into their design new energy efficiency elements that reduce the energy consumption for heating and hot water in the residential buildings below the current thermal standards in force

179 thousand tons of CO2eq
The design and construction documentations for three pilot buildings in Hrodna Mahiliou and Minsk developed by the project have been submitted for the required state expertise New energy efficiency measures have been adopted into the design of these buildings ventilation heat recuperation heat pumps on sewage and geothermal sources solar heaters and solar PVpanels The project has been already proceeded to procurement of related equipment accessories and tools These provisions allow the projected annual specific energy consumption for space heating and hot water supply to be in the range of 5060 kWhm2 that is by ca 6070 kWhm2 per year lower than in the baseline case
If this design value is proven by actual construction the lifetime 30 years GHG emission reduction will be at least 179 thousand tons of CO2eq for the three buildings in total

description.narrative: Number of buildings designed and constructed in accordance with the new energy efficiency standards

comment.narrative: At least 10 around 80 buildings of all new residential multistorey buildings for which the design is started during the last year of the project are integrating new EE measures into their design with the target of reducing their combined annual energy demand for space heating and hot water below 60 kWhm2

There are no buildings constructed under the auspices of the project yet
The entire design and construction documentations have been completed by the project for three pilot buildings The documentations have been submitted to the State Construction Expertise for approval In these buildings according to their design the specific annual energy consumption for space heating and hot water supply will be less than 55 kWhm2
Since 2013 12 buildings apart from 3 project pilot buildings above are being designed using principles grounded and promoted by the project In these buildings the energy consumption for space heating already reduced to ca 30 kWhm2

description.narrative: Demonstrated energy and costsaving potential of new energy efficiency measures in at least three new residential buildings in two Belarusian cities
Status of the demonstration projects

comment.narrative: NA

Each of the 3 demonstration buildings constructed and reaching the target for annual external energy demand for space heating and hot water equal or less than 60 kWhm2 and their energy consumption and other performance living comfort etc monitored for at least one full year Full completion of this outcome without project extension is moderately unlikely because of oneyear delay of the project start If the documented disseminated and institutionalized project results should be based on the results of the three buildings being built then completion of this Outcome without project extension is unlikely
The baseline costs of the 3 demo buildings is covered in full by the projects cofinancing resources and the GEF financing for incremental EE measures will not exceed 15 of the total construction costs of each demo building

None of the three demonstration buildings has been constructed and monitored yet
Background studies preconstruction simulations and exploratory designs of measures technological methods installations and equipment for energy efficiency improvement of three pilot buildings and design of all three selected pilot buildings have been completed along with application of integrated building design principles and taking into account new technologies and approaches suggested and formulated by the project
The design and construction documentations of all three pilot buildings in Hrodna Mahiliou and Minsk have been developed and submitted to the state expertise for approval The construction documentation of the pilot building in Hrodna has been approved Such approval for construction documentations of other two buildings is expected in July 2015
The project has already procured of about 15 of all equipment accessories and tools and started procurement procedures for the rest
In line with the commitments assumed in writing by the project partners they have covered the baseline cost of design and construction documentations for all three pilot buildings Recently the GrodnoGrazhdanProject informed the PIU that they will not be able to provide further sustainable financing of the pilot house in Grodno The PIU and UNDP CO have in cooperation with the Head of EE Department approached the Grodno authorities to settle this issue As a result another builder is ready to take over the initiative and commit itself to provide necessary financing of the construction in Grodno The project is currently waiting for a formal letter The two other partners reconfirmed in writing their financial commitments to support the baseline construction proven by corresponding Oblast authorities and submitted timeframes for design and construction of pilot buildings in Minsk and Mogilev
According to the design and construction documentations the energy performance of these buildings will be in line with the outcome target which stipulates for annual external energy demand for space heating and hot water supply to be equal or less than 60 kWhm2 and the cost of incremental energy efficiency measures will not exceed 15 of the total construction costs

description.narrative: Documented disseminated and institutionalized project results providing a basis for further replication

Status of the planned public outreach activities
Status of the entity to follow up and continue the activities initiated by the project
Number of visit and downloads from the project website

comment.narrative: NA

Planned public outreach activities successfully completed
An entity to follow up and as applicable to continue the activities initiated by the project has been designated with adequate resources to perform its work
At least 100 hits and 20 downloaded documents per month from the project website by outside visitors

Public outreach activities being successfully implemented
14 communication campaigns 5 international conferences 5 round tables 2 international seminars abroad one pressconference 6 training workshops one Earth Day Event one 3DPicture Event two exhibitions
39 pressreleases and 67 articles published in webbased media
148 technical reports and 16 brochures printed or published in webbased media
40 news pieces broadcasted The partnership network includes more than 25 media resources
Support has been provided for 20122013 and 20132014 Energy Marathon Republican Contest The PMU was taking part in the Contest Committee The Contest materials have been prepared published and disseminated in 500 CDs among schools relevant Universities and the Ministry of Education
No state agency with a responsibility to monitor the energy savings and CO2 emission reductions in residential buildings has been mandated and capacitated yet This activity was initially planned for 20152016
In average per month 190 hits and 1700 documents are being downloaded by outside visitors
The project website test version was created as of 01122013 The fully operated version was launched on 19122013 The website is being regularly updated wwweffbuildby

description.narrative: Enhanced capacity of the Belarusian specialists to implement and effectively enforce new energy efficiency standards and construction norms with the initial focus on new residential buildings
Demonstrated capacity of the Belarussian building sector specialist to integrate new EE approaches and measures into the design of the buildings and to implement them in practice

comment.narrative:
Nonintegrated design of the buildings just complying with the current prescriptive thermal standards in force
Lack of capacity of the public authorities to effectively supervise and enforce the implementation of the planned new overall energy performance based norms and standards

Integrated energy efficient building design approach together with buildings overall energy performance based design principles adopted into the work of at least 30 of all local design institutes as well as into the curricula of all educational institutes in Belarus educating new architects and building construction and HVAC engineers
By the end of the project at least 50 experts from each key professional group see outputs 2226 and 200 university students have taken and successfully passed courses on energy efficient building design and constructionKey public authorities responsible for supervision and enforcement of the planned new norms and regulations trained

6
There are already 7 local design institutes ie NIPTIS MAPID Hrodnagrazhdanproekt Gomelgrazhdanproekt SaintGobain Construction Product BelRus Tenth UNR Minskproekt out of ca 120 design institutes operating in the field of civil construction engineering which are introducing in their practice design and construction of residential buildings with energy efficiency improvement components developed and advocated by the project
The project developed and disseminated about 40 special technical reports and guidelines on energy efficiency design principles The recommendations with cost efficiency analysis of different technical options applicable to the development of energy efficient residential buildings were prepared and discussed with stakeholders The recommendations are intended to be tested during the development of pilot buildings and will be included in national technical regulations and standards
More than 70 specialists
The analysis of target groups along with assessment of needs in their capacity building has been conducted and the capacity building action plan for 20142016 has been compiled discussed with Energy Efficiency Department and other stakeholders and approved Training textbooks have been drafted and disseminated
More than 70 specialists has developed their skills and increased knowledge for leading and managing effective energy audit in residential houses during three twoday training courses organized in Sep Oct and December 2014 One training course was conducted during actual energy audit measurements onsite
More than 70 specialists has taken and passed sixday training courses held in Hrodna and Minsk on energy efficient building design and construction new energy efficiency improvement policy norms and standards The trainings were attended by 29 companies designers engineers builders construction inspectors utilities representatives etc
The project provided support and organized logistics for 9 study visits and 10 international events abroad where about 30 decisionmakers designers builders and other relevant specialists have become acquainted with design construction and operation practices as well as with legal framework standards and policies exercised in four leading European countries Germany Austria England and France in the field of energy efficient residential buildings
No syllabus related to energy efficient building design principles has been adopted into the curricula of target educational institutes in Belarus yet No student has passed the courses yet
The critical analysis of curricula of different relevant universities has been conducted and the proposals for its improvement and updating have been presented in a project report along with a list of suggested university courses Based on the report recommendations for relevant university curricular updates have been drafted presented and approved at two roundtables about 60 representatives of stakeholders have participated
Three new courses related to the best international and national practice in the field of design and construction of energy efficient residential buildings were suggested and presented by the project During roundtable discussions held in the Belarusian National Technical University conjointly with Scientific Council Meeting with presence of representatives from 14 faculties of 7 universities three national universities agreed to include these new courses in their syllabi The decision has been made to continue cooperation with the said faculties in order to further adjust the curricular materials prepared by the project to current syllabi

description.narrative: Strengthened legal and regulatory framework and mechanisms to enforce the legislation for improving the energy efficiency of the building sector with the focus on new residential buildings
Status of the national laws and other regulatory documents controlling the energy consumption of the newly constructed buildings

comment.narrative: Prescriptive thermal standards adopted in 2010 defining minimum mandatory Uvalues for the building envelope corresponding to the average annual heat demand of 60 kWhm2 for space heating of typical multiapartment buildings and 120130 kWh m2 together with sanitary hot water preparation

Revised minimum energy performance standards adopted for new construction and reaching a status of a law by the end of the project with a target of reducing the energy consumption of new residential buildings for space heating and hot water together below 60 kWhm2
An energy performance certification and labelling scheme for both new and existing buildings adopted and under implementation by the end of the project

No minimum energy performance standards reaching a status of a law have been adopted yet
The project elaborated a draft of the Technical Code On Energy Efficiency of Buildings which is based on EU Directive 201031EU concerning integral energy performance of residential buildings along with the list of related national technical regulatory acts These documents were incorporated into the Plan of State Standardization for 2015 and into the State Development Program of Technical Regulation Standardization and Conformity Assessment in the Field of Energy Saving for 20112015 Both programmes were duly adopted and the project submitted the drafts of elaborated documents to the Technical Committee for Standardization in the Field of Energy Efficiency TCS14 for consideration and approval The said TCS14 was created by the Ministry of Architecture and Construction due to initiatives and support provided by the project Three project consultants were coopted to be members of TCS14 and one of them has become a chair of TCS14
As an integral part of national applications to the said Technical Code the project drafted some new standards Some of these standards have been already submitted and adopted in particular Method of calculation of specific heat consumption for heating and ventilation in residential buildings Energy performance of buildings Assessment of overall energy consumption and energy performance of buildings Energy efficiency of buildings Methods for determination of energy efficiency and energy certification buildings amendments to Thermal protection of buildings Energy performance characteristics Rules of definition
The project has prepared a draft of the methodological guidelines based on the IPMVprotocol and in line with the best international practice and with due account of national provisions for energy audit and energy performance monitoring and calculation applicable to residential buildings The draft has been verified during energy auditing of 30 multistorey residential buildings in 20132015 and adjusted accordingly It will be used for carrying out of energy audits of 25 other multistorey residential buildings in 20152016 and further enter a corresponding adoption procedure Four twoday training workshops were organized and held in 20132014 for more than 70 professional energy auditors
No energy performance certification and labeling scheme for residential buildings have been adopted yet
In technical standard Energy efficiency of buildings Methods for determination of energy efficiency and energy certification of buildings the project and its partners first introduced a scheme similar to the energy performance certification system This scheme is suggested in a building energy efficiency passport format which is to be issued as an integral part of design and construction documentations and contains all major requisites for energy performance certification Next in the second part of 2015 the project should elaborate practical procedures for the energy certification system and a system of monitoring and compliance checking applicable to residential buildings
To do this the project organized and held two roundtables for relevant stakeholders where main principles and framework of the certification system were discussed and provided further necessary consulting services to the StroyTechNorm RUE and to members of the TCS14 As of Nov 26 2014 the suggestions mentioned above were considered and approved by the said Technical Committee for further adoption procedure The project will continue its efforts in consulting the authorities using in particular such instrument as TCS14 until the said documents are duly adopted

description.narrative: Landscape approach to management of peatlands aiming at multiple ecological benefits.
Landscape approach to management of peatlands aiming at multiple ecological benefits
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: To promote a landscape approach to management of peatlands so as to conserve biodiversity, enhance carbon stocks, and secure multiple ecosystem services with demonstration in the Poozerie landscape.

description.narrative: Environment - policy, planning and administration

To promote a landscape approach to management of peatlands that conserves biodiversity enhances carbon stocks ensures sustainable land management and sustainable forest management with demonstrations in a number of pilot sites peatland PAs agricultural peatlands and forested peatlands
Extent of peatland area that is brought under an effective landscapebased conservation andor sustainable use regime under the framework of a National Strategy for Peatlands NSP

comment.narrative: Currently there is no NSP there are a few disparate efforts through past and ongoing donorfunded projects to restore conserve and sustainably use peatlands

122270 ha
Of which 30301 ha are existing peatland national zakazniks where management effectiveness is improved 25036 ha are new local zakazniks 45000 ha is the network of environmental corridors 15000 ha of drainage networks on agricultural peatlands from which sedimentation is to be reduced 4311 ha are rewetted agricultural lands 495 ha are arable peatlands converted to meadows 100 ha are arable peatlands subject to layered ploughing and 2027 ha are rewetted forest peatlands

59337 ha
13927 ha reserved at the local level for establishing of 7 new reserves 25000 ha of new reserves will be officially gazzeted by end of 2016 An a network of environmental corridors covering 45000 ha established
An engineering project to establish a drainage network covering 15000 ha on agricultural peatlands developed to reduce adverse impact of anthropogenic runoffs from landreclamation systems on ecosystems of the Zvanest reserve works will be completed by mid 2016
An engineering project for rewetting of 3455 ha of agricultural lands developed 400 ha of arable peatlands converted to meadows 10 ha of arable peatlands subject to layered ploughing and engineering projects for rewetting of 3384 ha forested peatlands developed

description.narrative: Landscape approach to peatlands conservation and sustainable use enshrined in national policy and implemented through a network of PAs in the Poozerie landscape
A network of environmental corridors in the Vitebsk Oblast Poozerie landscape ensuring the continuity of the natural landscapes and unrestricted wildlife migration

comment.narrative: Isolated elements of the network are in place which are not considered in territorial planning
An environmental network is developed comprised of the key territories and environmental corridors linking bogs and wet areas together by Year 3
Environmental Network for Vitebsk Oblast Poozerie was established and duly approved be the Ministry of Environment and Vitebsk Regional Executive Committee

description.narrative: A network of local caretakers is operational in the internationally important peatland PAs

comment.narrative: At present system of local caretakers are in 8 important peatland PAs
Network exists for 18 internationally important peatland PAs by Year 3

Activities are planned for 20152016 In 2015 an agreement with a leading national NGO in this area Akhova ptushak Batskaushchyny was reached and preliminar financial and working plan was worked out In September 2015 official agreement on implementation of this activity will be signed It presumes using of NIM modality

description.narrative: Criteria and methodologies for assessment of peatlands state function and services

comment.narrative: Criteria exist but they only take into account economic benefits
Criteria and methodology developed by Year 2 and includes ecological criteria in the form of recommendations instructions
A technical code on criteria including ecological ones for peatlands use developed and duly approved by Ministry of Environemnt on f June 26th 2015 1712082015 33140

description.narrative: Crosssectoral WG for promoting a landscape approach to peatlands conservation and sustainable use

comment.narrative: None exists at present
Working Group formed by Year 1 and receives capacity building support from partner international peatland conservation organizations
Another two meetings of the Working Group took place in November 2014 and February 2015 where main provisions of the Strategy and Schemes were approved

description.narrative: National Strategy for Peatlands

comment.narrative: Old Scheme ended in 2010 and emphasis was on peat mining and agriculture
New 20year strategy that takes economic and ecological benefits into account in determining use of peatlands by Year 4

Strategy for sustainable use of peatlands until 2030 and Schemes of peatland distribution with instructions on the use of peatlands are developed and being reviewed Final documents are expected by December 2015

See target values for pilot sites in table below

Biodiversity inventory at pilot sites 8 territories of over 8000 ha was completed before rewetting Flora and fauna charactiristic were recorded It was shown that for the pilot territories the most typical vegetation type is pine forests growing in an unstable hydrological regime with signs of digression Populations of birds indictor species are characterized by significant lower levels in comparison with target numbers Monitoring works will continue in 20152017 after rewetting

emission of CO2 was 511 278 gСО2Cm2 for biotope dominated by Polytrichum commune on raised bogs with disturbed hydrological regime

The CH4 emission was negligible at all sites

OFFICE OF THE HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR HUMA
OFFICE OF THE HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR HUMA
OFFICE OF THE HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR HUMA

description.narrative: Indicator(s): 1. The ITC training programmes updated to reflect the advanced anti-trafficking methods and best practices in response to the existing needs. 2. Human rights and gender equality topics integrated in the programme contents. 3. Five training courses for 125 law-enforcement professionals conducted in the field of combating trafficking in hu-man beings and related offences. Indicators: 1. An enhanced system is in place to sup-port coordination and information ex-change on human trafficking and related offences among the law enforcement agencies and other competent authorities of Belarus and the neighbouring states. 2. Strengthened human rights focus of in-ternational cooperation against human trafficking among the members of the Group of Friends and international organi-sations.

comment.narrative:
Baseline: The contents of the existing training programmes on combating human trafficking and related of-fences need to be upgraded and updated with regard to the latest trends in the criminal context dynamics. Advanced international anti-trafficking methods, including those for Internet, have to be researched and introduced. The focus to strengthen human rights and gender equality needs to be enhanced. Baseline: There is a need to improve the effectiveness of measures to prevent the victimization of women and children, as well as to elaborate a coordinat-ed approach to addressing the root causes of trafficking.
There is a need to improve coordination of the relevant agencies of the Group of Friends to hu-man trafficking to develop more uniform ap-proaches to protecting the human rights of vic-tims of human trafficking.

75 professionals from Belarus, the CIS and neighbouring coun-tries have completed training courses in the field of combat-ing trafficking in human beings and related offences. Human rights and gender per-spective topics are integrated into the training curriculum. Advanced methods of detec-tion, recording and investiga-tion of crimes related to human trafficking have been incorpo-rated in the professional prac-tices of the law enforcement agencies from Belarus, CIS and neighbouring countries repre-sented at the training courses.
30 law-enforcement profession-als and other competent authorities from Belarus, Russia, Lithuania, Estonia, Moldova, Kazakhstan and other countries have taken part in the workshop. Exchange of information on anti-trafficking and coordination among the law enforcement agencies and other competent authorities in Belarus and other states in the region have been optimized.
30 representatives of the Mem-ber States of the Group of Friends United against Human Trafficking have taken part in the international workshop. A uniform position has been formulated on the application of international human rights standards to protecting the victims of human trafficking and for strengthening law enforcement cooperation against human trafficking among the member states of the Group of Friends and the relevant international organisa-tions.

83 professionals from Belarus, the CIS and neighbouring countries have completed training courses in the field of combat-ng trafficking in human beings and related offences. Human rights and gender perspective topics were an integral part of the training curriculum.Advanced methods of detection, recording and investigation of crimes related to human trafficking were incorporated in the professional practices of the law enforcement agencies from Belarus, CIS and neighbouring countries represented at the training courses. 54 law-enforcement professionals and other competent authorities from Belarus, neigbouring countries took part in the workshop.As a result of it, the participants exchanged of experience and best practices of combating human trafficking and other forms of modern slavery Exchange of information on anti-trafficking and coordination among the law enforcement agencies and other competent authorities in Belarus and other states in the region have been optimized. Based on its successful experience from 2013, UNDP and OHCHR supported global dialogue on trafficking in human beings in the context of human rights. In particular, the second international workshop for representatives of competent authorities of the Member States of the Group of Friends United against Human Trafficking (UN-wide initiative of Belarus) took place in Minsk to spur further cooperation and coordination in the area, with particular focus on children's vulnerability 42 representatives of the Member States of the Group of Friends United against Human Trafficking have taken part in the international workshop as well as 12 representatives of international organizations.

1. 130 professionals from Belarus, the CIS and neighboring countries have completed training courses in the field of combating trafficking in human beings and related offenses. 2. Human rights and gender perspective topics are integrated into the training curriculum. 3. Advanced methods of detection, recording and investigation of crimes related to human trafficking have been incorporated in the professional practices of the law enforcement agencies from Belarus, CIS and neighboring countries represented at the training courses. 4. 30 law-enforcement professionals and other competent authorities from Belarus, International organizations and NGOs have taken part in the workshop. 5. Exchange of information on anti-trafficking and coordination among the law enforcement agencies and other competent authorities in Belarus, International organizations and NGOs have been optimized.

1. 3 workshops were conducted with the total number of participants equaling to 125. 2. Exchange of information on anti-trafficking and coordination among the law enforcement agencies and other competent authorities in Belarus have been optimized with participation of representatives from international organizations, NGOs, over 50 national ministries and embassies representatives. 3. Advanced methods of detection, recording and investigation of crimes related to human trafficking have been incorporated in the professional practices of the law enforcement agencies from Belarus, CIS and neighbouring countries represented at the training courses.

1. 2 Training courses on multi-agency child safeguarding and tackling child sexual exploitation held. 2. 30 representatives of stakeholder ministries and law enforcement entities (Ministry of Internal Affairs, Ministry of Justice, Ministry of Education, Ministry of Labour, Ministry of Health, Ministry of Social Protection, State Boarder Committee) have completed training courses in the field of multi-agency child safeguarding and tackling child sexual exploitation.

1. 2 Training courses on multi-agency child safeguarding and tackling child sexual exploitation held as scheduled. 2. 30 representatives of stakeholder ministries and law enforcement entities (Ministry of Internal Affairs, Ministry of Justice, Ministry of Education, Ministry of Labor, Ministry of Health, Ministry of Social Protection, State Boarder Committee) have completed training courses in the field of multi-agency child safeguarding and tackling child sexual exploitation.
